title: 112_s675
content: The Apology Resolution, enacted in 1993, apologized to Native Hawaiians for the US role in the overthrow of the Kingdom of Hawaii. A report in 2000 recommended legislation to recognize Native Hawaiian sovereignty over their lands. The United States supports the recognition of a government-to-government relationship with a Native Hawaiian governing body, as outlined in the United Nations Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples. Hawaii has long supported Federal legislation to recognize Native Hawaiian sovereignty. The State of Hawaii has long supported Federal recognition of the Native Hawaiian people and their governing entity, as evidenced by the enactment of Act 195 in 2011. This act recognizes Native Hawaiians as the only indigenous people of Hawaii, urges Federal recognition of their governing entity, and establishes the Native Hawaiian Roll Commission to facilitate their reorganization. The curr_chunk is a section titled "SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS." In this Act, the term "Council" refers to the Interim Governing Council, "indigenous, native people" are the original inhabitants who exercised sovereignty over areas later part of the US, "Native Hawaiian governing entity" is the sovereign governing body of Native Hawaiians, and "Native Hawaiian Roll Commission" is the Commission established under Act 195 (2011). The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior, and "special political and legal relationship" describes the connection between the United States and federally recognized Indian tribes. SEC. 4. POLICY AND PURPOSE. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior, and "special political and legal relationship" describes the connection between the United States and federally recognized Indian tribes. It is the policy of the United States that Congress has the authority to address the conditions of the Native Hawaiian people, who have rights to autonomy, self-determination, self-governance, reorganize a governing entity, and become economically self-sufficient. The US reaffirms its special relationship with the Native Hawaiian people. The United States reaffirms its authority to address the welfare of Native Hawaiian people and ensures parity in policy and treatment among all indigenous groups. The purpose of this Act is to provide a process for reconciliation and political relations with the Native Hawaiian people. The Act aims to establish a process for the reorganization and Federal recognition of a single Native Hawaiian governing entity with self-government powers similar to other federally recognized Indian tribes. The Act aims to establish a process for the reorganization and Federal recognition of a single Native Hawaiian governing entity with self-government powers similar to other federally recognized Indian tribes. SEC. 5. REORGANIZATION OF THE NATIVE HAWAIIAN GOVERNING ENTITY. The Act recognizes the right of Native Hawaiian people to reorganize a governing entity for their common welfare. The Secretary is tasked with carrying out duties related to this recognition. Members are those listed on the Native Hawaiian Roll Commission's certified roll for reorganization purposes. The Act allows for the reorganization of a Native Hawaiian governing entity, with an Interim Governing Council established by members on the roll. The Council represents members in implementing the Act. The Act allows for the reorganization of a Native Hawaiian governing entity through an Interim Governing Council. The Council has limited powers as provided by the Act and can enter into contracts or obtain grants to fulfill its duties. Within 2 years of all members being elected, the Council must gather input from members on the roll to develop a proposed constitution and bylaws for the governing entity. The Interim Governing Council must develop a proposed constitution and bylaws for the Native Hawaiian governing entity, provide it to all members, hold elections with the assistance of the Secretary, and submit the ratified constitution and bylaws for approval. The Interim Governing Council must develop a proposed constitution and bylaws for the Native Hawaiian governing entity, hold elections with the assistance of the Secretary, and submit the ratified constitution and bylaws for approval. The Council will cease to exist once all officers of the Native Hawaiian governing entity are installed. SEC. 6. APPLICABILITY OF OTHER FEDERAL LAWS. The Native Hawaiian governing entity has the powers of self-government of an Indian tribe, including determining membership and being considered an Indian tribe for certain purposes. They are also subject to the Indian Gaming Regulatory Act. The Native Hawaiian governing entity, considered an Indian tribe for certain purposes, is subject to the Indian Gaming Regulatory Act and may not conduct gaming activities without permission from the State of Hawaii. The Secretary may recognize the entity as an Indian tribe under the Indian Reorganization Act. The ratification and confirmation of actions taken by the Secretary under the Indian Reorganization Act for the Native Hawaiian governing entity are upheld, specifically regarding federal recognition or jurisdiction on June 18, 1934. SEC. 7. SEVERABILITY. If any provision of this Act is held invalid, the remaining provisions shall continue in full force and effect. SEC. 8. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Sums necessary for carrying out this Act are authorized to be appropriated.
